#Text=Biologist Nick Bos tells Wikinews about ' self-medicating ' ants
#Text=Tuesday , September 1 , 2015
#Text=Formica fusca
#Text=, from file .
#Text=Image : Mathias Krumbholz .
#Text=Nick Bos , of the University of Helsinki , studies " the amazing adaptations social insects have evolved in order to fight the extreme parasite pressure they experience " .
#Text=In a recently-accepted Evolution paper Bos and colleagues describe ants appearing to self-medicate .
#Text=I have no doubt that as time goes on , there will be more and more cases documented
#Text=The team used Formica fusca , an ant species that can form thousand-strong colonies .
#Text=This common black ant eats other insects , and also aphid honeydew .
#Text=It often nests in tree stumps or under rocks and foraging workers can sometimes be spotted climbing trees .
#Text=Some ants were infected with Beauveria bassiana , a fungus .
#Text=Infected ants chose food laced with toxic hydrogen peroxide , whereas healthy ants avoided it .
#Text=Hydrogen peroxide reduced infected ant fatalities by 15 % , and the ants varied their intake depending upon how high the peroxide concentration was .
#Text=In the wild , Formica fusca can encounter similar chemicals in aphids and dead ants .
#Text=The Independent
#Text=reported self-medicating ants a first among insects .
#Text=Bos obtained his doctorate from the University of Copenhagen .
#Text=He began postdoctoral research at Helsinki in 2012 .
#Text=He also runs the AntyScience blog .
#Text=The blog aims to help address " a gap between scientists and ' the general public ' .

column1: #Text=He now discusses his work with Wikinews .
#Text=Beauveria bassiana
#Text=on a cicada in Bolivia .
#Text=Image : Danny Newman .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What first attracted you to researching ants ?
#Text=Nick Bos
#Text=Me and a studymate were keeping a lot of animals during our studies , from beetles , to butterflies and mantids , to ants .
#Text=We had the ants in an observation nest , and I could just look at them for hours , watching them go about .
#Text=This was in my third year of Biology study I think .
#Text=After a while I needed to start thinking about an internship for my M. Sc . studies , and decided to write a couple of professors .
#Text=I ended up going to the Centre for Social Evolution at the University of Copenhagen where I did a project on learning in Ants under supervision of Prof. Patrizia d'Ettorre .
#Text=I liked it so much there I ended up doing a PhD and I 've been working on social insects ever since .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What methods and equipment were used for this investigation ?
#Text=NB
#Text=This is a fun one .

#Text=I try to work on a very low budget , and like to build most of the experimental setups myself ( we actually have equipment in the lab nicknamed the ' Nickinator ' , ' i-Nick ' and the ' Nicktendo64 ' ) .
#Text=There 's not that much money in fundamental science at the moment , so I try to cut the costs wherever possible .
#Text=We collected wild colonies of Formica fusca by searching through old tree-trunks in old logging sites in southern Finland .
#Text=We then housed the ants in nests I made using Y-tong [ aerated concrete ] .
#Text=It 's very soft stone that you can easily carve .
#Text=We carved out little squares for the ants to live in ( covered with old CD covers to prevent them escaping ! ) .
#Text=We then drilled a tunnel to a pot ( the foraging arena ) , where the ants got the choice between the food with medicine and the food without .
